Tommy made his way to the lunchroom, scanning the tables for any sign of a friendly face. He had a vague memory of seeing someone in one of his classes, but he couldn't quite place him. As he made his way towards the back of the room, he spotted the boy sitting by himself, staring at his phone.

"Hey," Tommy said, taking a seat across from him. "We have English together, right?"

The other boy looked up, startled. "Yeah, I think so. You're Tommy, right?"

Tommy nodded. "Yeah, that's me. And you're...?"

"Mark," the boy said. "Mark Reynolds."

They sat in silence for a moment, the sounds of the other students eating and talking around them. Tommy didn't know what to say, but he could sense that Mark was feeling just as awkward as he was.

"So, uh, how's English going for you?" Tommy asked, grasping for a topic of conversation.

Mark shrugged. "It's okay, I guess. I hate writing papers, though."

Tommy nodded in agreement. "Yeah, me too. It's like, how are we supposed to know what they want us to say?"

They both laughed, and for a moment, Tommy felt like he might have found a kindred spirit.

But then, the sound of raucous laughter caught their attention. Tommy turned to see a group of boys approaching their table, led by a tall, broad-shouldered kid with a sneer on his face.

"Well, well, well, what do we have here?" the kid said, glancing between Tommy and Mark. "Looks like a couple of losers trying to make friends."

Tommy's heart sank. He had seen this kid around school before, but he didn't know his name. All he knew was that he was one of the popular kids, and he and his friends seemed to take pleasure in tormenting anyone they saw as weak or different.

"Leave us alone," Tommy said, trying to sound tough.

The kid just laughed. "Or what? You gonna cry to your mommy?"

The other boys around him snickered, and Tommy felt a familiar surge of anger and despair. He hated feeling so powerless, so vulnerable, but he didn't know what to do to make it stop.

Mark shifted uncomfortably in his seat. "Come on, guys, leave them alone."

But the tall kid just turned his sneer on Mark. "Who asked you, Reynolds? Go back to your little hole and play on your phone."

Mark's face flushed with anger, but he didn't say anything else. He just stood up and started to back away.

Tommy felt a surge of desperation. He didn't want to be left alone with these bullies again. He didn't want to feel so weak and helpless.

But he didn't know what to do.

The tall kid leaned in closer. "What's wrong, Tommy? Cat got your tongue?"

Tommy clenched his fists, but he didn't say anything. He just glared at the kid, hoping that somehow he could make him go away.

It didn't work.

The other boys started to join in, calling him names and making fun of his clothes, his hair, everything about him.

Tommy felt a sense of numbness wash over him. He didn't know how much longer he could take this.

And then, just as suddenly as they had appeared, the bullies started to back away. Tommy looked up to see a teacher walking towards them, and the tall kid and his friends started to scatter.

But the damage was already done.

Tommy sighed with relief as he finally got out of the school building. He had hoped the teasing and insults would be left behind with the walls of the school, but he was wrong. A group of older teens in a car sped by him and yelled out their window. "Hey, nerd!" one of them shouted. "Watch out or we might just run you over!" Tommy was frozen in place for a moment, heart racing, until they drove away.

He got on his bike and rode the short distance to his house, trying to shake off the feeling of dread. When he got home, he threw his backpack on the floor and went straight to his room. The walls were adorned with posters of his favorite comic book characters and action figures were scattered on the shelves. He sat down at his desk and opened up his laptop, hoping to distract himself with some of his favorite online forums.

After a few minutes, he slammed the laptop shut and let out a frustrated groan. He felt disconnected from everything and everyone around him. He got up and walked over to his bookshelf, looking for something to take his mind off of the day's events. He settled on an old science fiction novel that he had read a dozen times before.

As he began to read, he felt his heart rate slow and his breathing return to normal. He was able to escape the cruel reality of his day and become lost in a world of spaceships and distant planets.

After a while, he put down the book and opened up his textbook, determined to get some studying done. He had always been a good student, and he hoped that his grades would provide some sense of validation in a world where he felt constantly put down.

But as he read the pages, he found himself unable to concentrate. He felt like he was drowning in a sea of words and numbers, and no matter how hard he tried, he just couldn't keep up.

He let out a frustrated growl and slammed his textbook shut. He sat back in his chair and looked around his room. His eye caught on a small Lego set that he had built when he was much younger. He hesitated for a moment, then got up and started putting the pieces together.

As he built, he felt his mind relax and his thoughts wander. For a moment, he forgot about the teasing and the isolation and just focused on the simple task at hand. It was a small moment of peace, but it was enough to make him feel just a little bit better.

Eventually, he finished the Lego set and looked at his clock. He realized that he had spent much more time building than he had intended and now had a pile of homework to do. He let out a sigh and picked up his textbook again, determined to get through the work, even if it took all night.
